I'm with David on being intrigued by the idea of using arbitrary classes. H=
owever, I'm much more interested in experiences than in votes. If someone s=
aid, "I went through my code and I could definitely use classes as categori=
es because of X, Y and/or Z," would be compelling to me. Even more compelli=
ng is if someone would write the test cases for the new scheme.

Regards,

=
Kent

On Nov 19, 2009, at 7:33 AM, David Saff wrote:

> On Wed, Nov 18, 200=
9 at 7:46 PM, yme0987654321 <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
> > The decisi=
on to use types to define categories is definitely surprising to see, so th=
at has to count against it.
> >
> > However, after the initial shock wears =
off, I definitely see the power in it, using Java inheritance and static ch=
ecking rather than free form strings and some arbitrary hierarchy delimiter=
 in the string.
> >
> > However, I think the decision to use a specific new=
 interface as the super type is not a good idea. It would seem you gain the=
 same power by allowing any Class<?>. The advantage of doing this is it wou=
ld allow real classes within the project to act as Categories, so that if, =
for example, I am testing a DAO framework, I can categorize individual test=
s with the specific DAO subclass they are targeting, and then run a categor=
y based on the DAO supertype. Much nicer than just calling it all SlowTests=
. In practice that won't happen often if a custom interface is required bec=
ause it will introduce a dependency on a JUnit type in the production code.=

> 
> Huh. The first time through, I thought "that's ridiculous". The
> sec=
ond time, I wondered if there's not something to this...
> 
> Totally musin=
g out loud, but you could rename the annotation as
> TestOf, so that you'd =
have
> 
> @TestOf(CustomStreamingPlatform.class)
> 
> Hmm...
> 
> > I'm als=
o curious if you considered using an annotation as the category? That is ha=
ving the category take a Class<?> that represents an annotation? You could =
support meta-annotations to allow a hierarchy of categories as well as supp=
orting any subclasses or implementations of types so annotated. Coding for =
that would be nasty business, but it wouldn't be complicated from a client =
point of view, and would allow the same flexibility of inheritance without =
the dependency on a JUnit type.
> 
> I wanted to stay away from meta-annota=
tions unless the reasons were
> _really_ compelling.
> 
> > I would prefer =
just an arbitrary Class<?>, though. Inheritance is well understood by any J=
ava programmer (unlike meta-annotations) and opens up a synergy between the=
 category hierarchy and the code hierarchy.
> 
> Can I get another vote on =
this extension idea?
> 
> David
